greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: First of two trees generated by floor[(3n-1)/2].
comment: This tree grows from (L(1),U(1))=(1,3).  The second tree, A183212, grows from (L(2),U(2))=(2,6).  Here, L(n)=floor[(3n-1)/2] and U(n)=3n.  The two trees are complementary in the sense that every positive integer is in exactly one tree.  The sequence formed by taking the terms of this tree in increasing order is A183213.  Leftmost branch of this tree: A183207.  Rightmost: A000244.  See A183170 and A183171 for the two trees generated by the Beatty sequence of sqrt(2).
link: Ivan Neretin, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..8192
formula: See the formula at A183209, but use L(n)=floor[(3n-1)/2] and U(n)=3n instead of L(n)=floor(3n/2) and U(n)=3n-1.
example: First four levels of the tree:
mathematica: a = {1, 3}; row = {a[[-1]]}; Do[a = Join[a, row = Flatten[{Quotient[3 # - 1, 2], 3 #} & /@ row]], {n, 5}]; a (* _Ivan Neretin_, May 25 2015 *)
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_, Dec 30 2010
